results.title: Maps are fun
results.brief_description: This film deals with the fundamental principles of map reading: scales, colour, symbols, and indexes and their uses are demonstrated. The whole film is designed as a preliminary introduction to the study of maps.

results.title: Maps & globes: An introduction
results.creator_credit: Roger Branson, James Ganzer and FilmFair Communications
results.brief_description: An introduction to the use of maps and globes. Covers scale direction and legend work as well as latitude and longitude.

results.title: Mappings
results.brief_description: Develops a concept of the interchangeability of the words ‘function’ and ‘mapping’. Shows a ‘function machine’ which responds predictably to a given numerical stimulus and gives the rule underlying the response. Good use of comical sketches to explain mathematical equations. From the series “Vision in mathematics”.

results.title: Mapping Australia
results.creator_credit: John Richardson, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Shows the stages in the production of maps, including aerial photography, ground surveys, and their conversion into map manuscripts. Show relationships of mapping to mineral and industrial development by tracing the stages in aluminium production from the initial discovery of bauxite at Weipa to the production plant at Bell Bay.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Richardson, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Maple syrup and sugar
results.brief_description: Explains how maple trees create maple sugar; how it is collected; and how it is then processed into final products. Includes Canadian custom of ‘sugaring off’ - a social event and celebration of spring and harvest time.
results.description: Explains how maple trees create maple sugar; how it is collected; and how it is then processed into final products. Includes Canadian custom of ‘sugaring off’ - a social event and celebration of spring and harvest time.

results.title: Maple Sugar Time
results.brief_description: Maple sugar time in Eastern Canada, showing old-time methods, When snow softens and ice begins to break its time to load the traditional equipment on a sleigh and go off to the sugar bush. “Sugaring off” is a spring social event for the French-Canadian farmer, who celebrates with a party.

results.title: Maple sugar
results.brief_description: Quebec produces about eighty percent of the worlds maple products. The film reports from the heart of the sugar country in Quebec’s Eastern Townships. All stages of processing are shown, from collecting the sap from the trees, to boiling, bottling and marketing. Also includes the Canadian custom of ‘sugaring off’, a celebration of spring and the first maple syrup gathered. Fresh hot syrup is poured onto snow to create maple toffee which is then eaten by everyone.

results.title: Mapantsula
results.creator_credit: Oliver Schmitz, Max Montocchio, David Hannay and Haverbeam
results.brief_description: The lives of Black South Africans in the township of Soweto are the background to this powerful, absorbing and thoughtful film. It is the first international Black African feature film and it was made under the noses of South African authorities, who thought it was a gangster film. Unlike many political films, “Mapantsula” is a story viewed through the eyes of an anti-hero, a small time black gangster known to his friends as Panic. Panic is a smooth opportunist who takes down anyone, white or black. In Zulu, Sotho and Afrikaans with English subtitles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Oliver Schmitz, Max Montocchio, David Hannay and Haverbeam

results.title: Mapandangare -the Great Baboon
results.brief_description: This film begins with an introduction to African musical instruments, showing how they are made and how they fit into basic musical families. The integral part music plays in African storytelling sessions comes to life as children respond in song to the story of the great baboon, Mapandangare. As the story unfolds it is possible to see why storytelling has been of such great importance for thousands of years.
